headline: Ohio primed for submarine yard, lawmakers say
author: Richard Payerchin
sentences: The bipartisan group also encouraged the Navy to consider establishing a Great Lakes maintenance facility, highlighting that Ohio possesses both a highly trained workforce and the facilities needed to readily develop the maintenance needs of the submarine force, according to the announcement from Portman’s office.

“Ohio would welcome the opportunity to address the maintenance backlog of the Navy in an effective and cost-efficient manner and could train a world-class workforce ready to meet the highly technical requirements associated with the maintenance and overhaul of the nuclear fast attack submarine fleet.”

“We urge you to expand and improve shipyard performance to increase readiness.”
The letter comes almost a week after Lorain Mayor Jack Bradley announced the city is working with Bartlett Maritime Corporation of Broadview Heights to establish a new submarine shipyard on the Black River.

Rob Portman and Democratic Sen. Sherrod Brown, and Democratic Reps. Marcy Kaptur, Tim Ryan and Shontel Brown sent a letter to U.S. Navy Secretary Carlos Del Toro asking about maintenance and repairs falling behind at the Navy’s four government-operated naval shipyards.

“These shipyards require specialized equipment, such as drydocks, and a highly-skilled workforce trained to the necessary exacting standards.”
The legislators pitched Ohio as the nation’s next site for submarine maintenance.

“Ohio has a highly-trained, technical workforce and many small and medium-sized firms that manufacture parts for construction and maintenance of America’s nuclear submarine and aircraft carrier fleets,” the letter said.

• Would additional private or government-owned shipyards capable of conducting maintenance on fast attack submarines significantly reduce the backlog of maintenance and get ships back to the operating forces faster?
“While there are efficiencies to be gained from improved processes, additional shipyards would allow more submarines to enter the maintenance cycle simultaneously and improve overall fleet readiness.

They also asked Del Toro to respond to four questions:
• Does the Navy see the current Los Angeles and Virginia Class fast attack submarine maintenance backlog as a detriment to overall readiness?
“Our nation’s Submarine Fleet plays an essential role in our national security and maintenance delays are degrading our nation’s readiness,” according to the letter from the delegation.
The congressional leaders cited a 2020 report from the Government Accountability Office that found 85 percent of submarine repairs were running late for fiscal years 2015-19.
“Submariners serving aboard these vessels spend months on end forward-deployed deterring adversaries and demonstrating commitment to the collective defense of our allies.
“It is clear from this and other reports that the current maintenance plan is not sufficient to meet the Navy’s submarine fleet’s maintenance needs,” the letter said.
The Navy should consider Ohio for a new shipyard that would address backlogs in maintaining the nation’s fleet of submarines, the state’s congressional leaders said.
